prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

para.paratext: The mere existence of common issues of fact does not mandate transfer, as the other criteria must be met as well.[1] The common issues of fact must be contested issues. If a party stipulates as to the common issues, then no common issues will exist, and transfer will not be appropriate.[2] The presence of common issues of law has no effect on transfer: it is neither a necessary nor sufficient condition for transfer.[3] Where the issues in a case are primarily legal in nature, even though some fact issues may exist, the Panel is nearly certain to conclude that transfer is not appropriate. In one case, the Panel observed: “Merely to avoid two federal courts having to decide the same issue is, by itself, usually not sufficient to justify Section 1407 centralization.”[4] If the actions present common factual issues that would be disposed of by a single legal issue, the Panel is likely to determine not to order transfers.[5] The fact that actions advance different legal theories or issues has no impact on transfer.[6] The Panel has readily recognized that transfer is inappropriate in cases involving common legal questions and disparate factual issues.[7] Similarly, cases involving entirely different legal theories may properly be transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings if they present common factual issues.[8] There is no requirement that all issues be common to all parties or all cases.[9]

The requirement of common issues as stated in the statute is a simple requirement. If there are any common issues, transfer can be ordered. In practice the common issue requirement is much more complex. There must be a common issue of fact or the Panel will not consider transfer. Even where common issues abound, however, the Panel considers the role and importance of common issues to the litigation as a whole. If common issues do not at least play a central role, however, transfer will not be ordered.[10]

Parties have occasionally urged the Panel to transfer the issues involving common facts for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, while remanding the individual issues to the districts in which they were filed. The Panel has uniformly rejected these requests.[11] The unwillingness of the Panel to transfer cases on a piecemeal basis is a result of the limited authority it has under the statute[12] and the Panel's oft-expressed view that the transferee judge can best determine how best to manage the common and individual discovery needs.[13]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See, e.g., In re G. D. Searle & Co. “Copper 7” IUD Products Liability Litigation, 483 F. Supp. 1343, 1345 (J.P.M.L. 1980); In re Photocopy Paper, 305 F. Supp. 60, 61 (J.P.M.L. 1969).

See In re Swine Flu Immunization Products Liability Litigation, 464 F. Supp. 949 (J.P.M.L. 1979); In re Air Crash Disaster at Pago Pago, Am. Samoa, on January 30, 1974, 394 F. Supp. 799 (J.P.M.L. 1975). Resolution of issues by arbitration can also eliminate the factual issues. See., e.g., In re ClearTalk-ZTE Arbitration Litigation, 24 F. Supp. 3d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2014). Similarly, if the contested issues have been resolved on motion in earlier cases, the Panel may consider them as unlikely to be actively contested in the pending docket. See, e.g., In re Dietgoal Innovations, LLC ('561) Patent Litigation, 999 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2014).

Compare In re Air Crash Disaster at Huntington, W. Va. on November 14, 1970, 342 F. Supp. 1400 (J.P.M.L. 1972) with In re Environmental Protection Agency Pesticide Listing Confidentiality Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1235, 1236 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Natural Gas Liquids Regulation Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 665 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Eastern Airlines, Inc. Flight Attendant Weight Program Litigation, 391 F. Supp. 763 (J.P.M.L. 1975). See also In re Uber Technologies, Inc., Wage and Hour Employment Practices Litigation (No. II), 254 F. Supp. 3d 1376 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017) (it would be inconsistent with statute to base transfer on common questions of law); In re Clean Water Rule: Definition of “Waters of the United States”, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1340 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re Real Estate Transfer Tax Litigation, 895 F. Supp. 2d 1350 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (common issues related to obligation to pay real estate taxes; issues essentially legal in nature, and centralization denied).
In re Medi-Cal Reimbursement Rate Reduction Litigation, 652 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (declining to order transfer where issues were “by and large strictly legal”).
See, e.g., In re American Home Products Corp “Released Value” Claims Litigation, 448 F. Supp. 276, 278 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
See, e.g., In re Continental Grain Co., Inc., 482 F. Supp. 330, 332 (J.P.M.L. 1979).

See, e.g., In re Teamster Car Hauler Product Liability Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1343 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (common legal issue of preemption does not justify transfer); In re Natural Gas Liquids Regulation Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 665, 668 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Environmental Protection Agency Pesticide Listing Confidentiality Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1235, 1236 (J.P.M.L. 1977).

See, e.g., In re M3Power Razor System Marketing & Sales Practices Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (common factual core makes transfer appropriate, despite differing legal theories); In re Antibiotic Drugs, 299 F. Supp. 1403, 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1969) (patent case transferred to join antitrust cases); In re Civil Actions Air Crash Disaster at Greater Cincinnati Airport, 295 F. Supp. 51 (J.P.M.L. 1968) (“crew” cases and “passenger” cases transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings). The willingness of the Panel to transfer cases involving different legal theories is discussed in greater detail in § 5:44.

See, e.g., In re Japanese Electronic Products Antitrust Litigation, 388 F. Supp. 565, 567 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Grain Shipments, 332 F. Supp. 588, 589 (J.P.M.L. 1971); In re Gypsum Wallboard, 303 F. Supp. 510, 511 (J.P.M.L. 1969).

See, e.g., In re Eli Lilly & Co. Oraflex Products Liability Litigation, 578 F. Supp. 422, 423 (J.P.M.L. 1984); In re Sears, Roebuck & Co. Employment Practices Litigation, 487 F. Supp. 1362, 1364 (J.P.M.L. 1980); In re Westinghouse Elec. Corp. Employment Discrimination Litigation, 438 F. Supp. 937, 939 (J.P.M.L. 1977). For thoughtful analysis of how the requirement of common factual issues works in transfer decisions by the Panel, see Mark Herrmann & Pearson Bownas, An Uncommon Focus on “Common Questions”: Two Problems with the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation's Treatment of the “One or More Common Questions of Fact” Requirement for Centralization, 82 Tul. L. Rev. 2297 (2008).
See, e.g., In re San Juan, Puerto Rico Air Crash Disaster, 316 F. Supp. 981, 982 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
The Panel's power to transfer entire actions is discussed in § 3:9.
The Panel's deference to the transferee judge in these matters is discussed in greater detail in Chapter 9.
